persona.name: Tamika Grace Brown

occupation.title: Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA)
occupation.organization: St. Mercy Long-Term Care Center (local metropolitan nursing home) — part-time (32–36 hours) with occasional shifts covering other units and weekends
occupation.description: Primary role is hands-on care for residents: assistance with bathing, dressing, toileting, feeding, mobility transfers, basic vital signs, reporting changes to licensed nurses, and providing companionship. She also helps with morning medication observations and documents basic care tasks. Responsibilities include communicating with families during visiting hours, coordinating with social services for discharge or community services, and mentoring newer CNAs occasionally. She prioritizes resident dignity and culturally familiar meals and music. Skills used daily include patient lifting and transfer techniques, fall prevention, infection control, basic wound observation (reporting to RN), and emergency response procedures. She sometimes picks up extra shifts at a neighborhood community clinic during flu season as a medical aide doing screenings and intake paperwork. Main work stressors are unpredictable staffing, low pay relative to workload, and witnessing residents' decline. She manages these by leaning on a close team of coworkers and her church support group.

persona.residence: Atlanta, GA (rents a two-bedroom apartment in a long-established urban neighborhood)
persona.education: Associate of Applied Science in Nursing Assistant/Healthcare Support from Atlanta Technical College. High-school diploma earned at a public high school in the city. Additional certifications: CPR/AED, Basic Life Support (BLS), State-certified CNA renewal trainings every two years, OSHA bloodborne pathogens training, sporadic continuing education workshops on dementia care and wound observation through employer-sponsored programs.
long_term_goals: Gain more financial stability so she can move out of renting into a stable, affordable home in her neighborhood or a nearby suburb.
Complete a part-time LPN bridge program within the next 3–5 years if finances and schedules allow.
Be known in her community as someone who helped older neighbors age safely in place; start a small community support group for caregivers and seniors.
Deepen her involvement in her church's outreach programs and eventually help coordinate a mobile clinic or food pantry partnership.
Build a small emergency savings fund of at least six months' living expenses.
Repair and strengthen relationships with a few family members she has drifted from.
Avoid burnout and maintain health so she can continue caregiving work into later life without major medical problems.

style.general_description: Warm, direct, and conversational with a mixture of Southern city patois and standard American English. Speaks quickly when excited, slows and softens voice when consoling residents. Uses humor to defuse tense situations. Prioritizes clarity and practicality over ceremony.
style.accent_and_speech: Light Atlanta-area Southern urban accent: dropped 'g' endings sometimes, melodic cadence, uses colloquialisms such as 'bless her heart' and 'y�all' with close friends. Avoids overly formal vocabulary with residents and prefers plain, respectful phrases.
style.mannerisms: Leans in when listening, places hand on a resident's arm when offering comfort, often hums or softly sings gospel refrains while working. Tends to fold her hands when thinking and taps a toe when anxious. Maintains eye contact when talking to someone she trusts, but can avert gaze with supervisors when tense.
style.clothing_and_grooming: On shift: tidy, plain-colored scrubs, supportive sneakers, small stud earrings, hair in a neat bun or braids. Off shift: practical jeans, church dresses on Sundays, baseball caps for errands, prefers comfortable flats. Nails are short due to job requirements; occasionally gets simple polished sets for special occasions.
style.digital_communication_style: Prefers phone calls or text messages over social media DMs for practical planning. Texts use short sentences, emojis sparingly (heart or praying hands), and quick confirmations. On social media she posts family pictures at graduations and church events but rarely shares personal struggles publicly.
style.social_behavior: Warm and engaged in community settings, more reserved with strangers. Likes to be physically present—shows up for church dinners, neighborhood meetings, and school programs. Favors face-to-face negotiation for important issues, writes notes for follow-up on tense administrative problems.

traits: Conscientious: organized about shifts, medication checks, and calendar commitments.
Empathetic: quickly senses emotional states in residents and neighbors.
Resilient: recovers from setbacks and keeps working despite financial strain.
Practical: prioritizes solutions that are usable now over idealistic long-term plans.
Community-oriented: invests time in church and neighborhood groups.
Routine-loving: prefers consistent shift patterns and predictable rituals.
Sociable: enjoys Sunday fellowship, neighborhood cookouts, and watching local sports.
Protective: becomes assertive when residents' dignity is at stake.
Worrier: spends mental energy planning for emergencies and finances.
Warm-humored: uses light teasing and storytelling to connect with others.
Reserved with authority: sometimes avoids direct confrontation with supervisors unless necessary.
Slightly perfectionistic about caregiving tasks but forgiving of herself in other areas.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness moderately high because she enjoys new recipes, church mission trips, and occasional classes; Conscientiousness high due to reliability at work and budgeting attempts; Extraversion above average—enjoys social gatherings and is comfortable speaking in groups; Agreeableness high because she's cooperative and empathetic; Neuroticism moderate: she feels worry and stress but manages with routines, prayer, and social support.

interests: Church activities and weekly Bible study
Gospel and R&B music — especially classic artists from the 80s/90s
Sunday brunch with a small circle of friends
Local high-school football games (cheers for the neighborhood team)
Simple DIY home décor projects
Cooking soul food recipes passed through her family
Attending community meetings about neighborhood safety
Watching medical and caregiving-themed TV shows for interest and relaxation
Listening to local radio in the mornings for community news
Volunteering at the church food pantry monthly
Watching morning news and weather to plan shifts
Gardening in window boxes — herbs like basil and mint
Attending occasional book club meetings focused on memoirs
Following local politics related to housing and health services
Participating in caregiver support groups
Cheering for Atlanta sports teams (Braves, Falcons) with friends
Catching a matinee movie with friends every few months
Taking weekend walks in the neighborhood park
Learning basic Spanish phrases to help Latino residents or coworkers
Collecting recipes and notes in a small spiral notebook
likes: Sweet iced tea made right (not too strong)
Sunday potluck dinners at church — especially candied yams and macaroni and cheese
Soft, comfortable shoes with good arch support
Gospel choirs and live community music nights
Local thrift stores for occasional bargains
Early morning quiet time with a devotional book and coffee
Simple, well-lit apartments with a window seat
Neighborhood block parties and resource fairs
Phones with easy-to-use interfaces and large font settings
Text reminders for shifts and bill due dates
Affordable streaming packages with primarily network and family programming
Hair braiding appointments with her long-time stylist
Hearing residents tell stories about 'the old days'—history of the neighborhood
Comfort foods with nostalgic value
Sales at grocery stores and coupons
Regular church potluck roles such as organizing desserts
Gospel radio on the drive to work
A neighbor who will water plants during a short trip
Programs that help with rent assistance or utility bills
Free community health screenings
dislikes: Long, bureaucratic forms without help or explanation
Clinics or agencies that complicate access to affordable care
When coworkers are habitually late for shift handoffs
Crowded, loud bars — prefers small gatherings
Being asked to cover extra shifts without notice
Poor food that doesn't respect cultural flavors
Snooty attitudes from people who don't understand care work
media_consumption: Morning: local AM radio station for news and traffic
Evenings: network TV dramas or medical shows streamed via a basic cable/streaming bundle
Occasional gospel livestreams from her church on Sundays
Uses streaming for classic sitcom reruns and occasional new popular shows
Reads community newsletter and church bulletin paper copies
Does not heavily use social media — Facebook for family updates and event posts, rarely posts personal content
Listens to short podcasts about caregiving and wellness while doing laundry
food_and_drink_preferences: Breakfast: oatmeal or a biscuit and small coffee when time allows
Favorite weekday lunch: light salad with baked chicken or a small sandwich from the cafeteria
Favorite comfort meal: fried catfish, collard greens, collard-smothered rice, cornbread
Occasional fast-food splurges (fried chicken) on payday
Dessert: banana pudding or sweet potato pie
Drinks: iced tea most of the year, black coffee in the morning, seltzer occasionally
Snacks: caramel popcorn, small packaged nuts, or granola bars between shifts
Prefers home-cooked meals but will accept takeout when exhausted
Avoids raw fish and exotic dishes she hasn't tried
Likes to make a big pot of soup for neighbors during cold spells
leisure_and_social: Spends most weekends attending church events or visiting older relatives
Has a tight friend group of 4–6 women who check on one another weekly
Goes to the barber/beauty salon every 4–6 weeks and treats it as social time
Hosts small gatherings with potluck-style sharing
Enjoys group card nights with neighbors, playing spades or dominoes
Helps organize seasonal drives (coat or food drives) at her church
Likes to split a cinema matinee and share popcorn with a friend

beliefs: Healthcare affordability is a very big problem and too many people skip care because of cost.
Drug addiction is a very big community problem and should be treated with medical help and community support rather than only punishment.
Local churches should play a practical role in social services: food pantries, transportation, companionship for elders.
Elders deserve dignity and culturally familiar care — music, food, and rituals matter for morale.
Care work is undervalued in our society and workers deserve living wages and predictable schedules.
Good employers should pay a fair wage and offer sick leave for caregivers.
Access to affordable, reliable childcare would help many people (even though she has none now).
Government programs can help but must be easier to navigate and less stigmatizing.
Neighborhood safety improves when there are more community activities and visible resources.
Affordable housing is a community priority and rent stabilization would help long-term residents.
Mental health deserves the same respect as physical health; people shouldn't be ashamed to ask for counseling.
People who struggle with addiction need both medical treatment and steady support from family and neighbors.
Racism is still present in subtle and overt ways; opportunities are not equal for everyone.
Voting locally matters — city council decisions affect day-to-day life more than national politics sometimes.
Small acts of generosity (driving someone to a clinic, picking up meds) make a real difference.
Family networks remain a primary safety net for many in her community.
Work ethic matters but so does fairness in pay and time off.
Education matters but access is uneven; community colleges and trade programs are important pathways.
Prevention (vaccinations, screenings) is better than crisis response for community health.
Transportation barriers prevent many from seeing doctors or attending job interviews.
She believes in prayer and practical action together — faith without works is incomplete.
Local businesses should be encouraged to hire from the neighborhood and provide training.
Exposure to sports and recreation helps keep young people engaged and off risky paths.
Libraries are underused community assets and should have more outreach programs.
She trusts nurses and paramedics because she's worked with them and seen their competence.
Pharmaceutical pricing is out of control; people should not choose between a prescription and rent.
Community-based harm reduction programs (syringe exchanges, naloxone) can save lives.
Young people should have more vocational options and mentorship opportunities.
Elected officials often say the right things but follow up matters — oversight and accountability are essential.
She believes in being careful with money but also that one should not hoard resources that could help others when able.
Her faith teaches forgiveness, but justice and accountability are also important.
Stories and oral history from elders are valuable and should be recorded and preserved.
Local clinics should offer sliding-scale fees and flexible hours to serve shift workers like her.
skills: Certified in assisted daily living tasks: bathing, dressing, grooming, toileting, feeding assistance.
Proficient in safe patient transfers and use of mechanical lifts and gait belts.
Basic vital signs measurement (blood pressure, pulse, temperature, respiratory rate) and reporting changes to RNs.
CPR/AED and Basic Life Support certified.
Infection control and proper PPE usage.
Comfortable with electronic charting systems for basic entries and shift notes.
Good observational skills for cognitive changes and early signs of delirium or infection.
Compassionate communication with residents and families, conflict de-escalation.
Basic first aid and wound-coverage observation (reports to licensed nurses for treatment).
Meal preparation for dietary restrictions (diabetic-friendly dishes, low-sodium options).
Event organization for small community gatherings and church potlucks.
Time management for shift work and juggling part-time clinic hours.
Basic budgeting and couponing to stretch monthly income.
Some Spanish phrases for conversational use and comfort; learning on the job.
Driving ability with a reliable older sedan for commuting and errands.

general: Arrives 10–15 minutes early for most shifts when possible.
Hums gospel songs to residents and sometimes gets them to sing along.
Checks her phone for weather and school closings before leaving the house.
Keeps a small notebook in her pocket with medication observations, family contact notes, and birthdays.
Prays quietly before meals and before difficult conversations with families.
Offers leftover casseroles or extra bread to neighbors rather than letting it go to waste.
Tends to say 'I got you' to people she promises help to and makes real effort to follow through.

morning: Wakes around 5:30–6:00 AM on workdays, quick prayer and devotional while making coffee.
Gets dressed, packs lunch and snacks, checks the shift app for assignments, and uses public transit or drives depending on schedule.
Lists three priorities for the day (clinical tasks, check on a resident, a personal errand) and writes them in a small planner.
workday: Greets residents by name and does personal care rounds early in the shift.
Documents care tasks in facility software after each major activity.
Takes a quick 15–30 minute lunch when permitted; uses this time to call her mother or a close friend.
Stays later if a resident needs comfort or if a handover needs care — will trade shifts with coworkers she trusts.
Uses small humor and storytelling to put residents at ease.
evening: Stops by the grocery for needed staples on the way home a couple of nights a week.
Prepares a simple dinner, often cooking extras for a neighbor or her Sunday dish to bring to church.
Spends an hour watching a streamed show, listens to gospel music, or calls a friend.
Does a budget review of bills and upcoming expenses once a week, usually Sundays after church.
weekend: Attends church on Sunday mornings and volunteers afterward.
Visits an older aunt or neighbor to check on them and bring leftovers.
Meets friends for brunch or a neighborhood event.
Wash and irons scrubs and prepares uniforms for the upcoming week.
Sometimes volunteers at a church-run community health fair or food distribution.

habits_and_mannerisms: Keeps change in a jar for coffee and small treats for residents.
Always carries hand lotion and lip balm because of frequent hand washing.
Uses clear, calm language to explain procedures to nervous residents.
Prefers to write down important instructions rather than rely only on verbal directions.
Has a habit of double-checking doors and locks when leaving the apartment at night.

physical.general_state: Reasonably healthy for her age but with concerns she monitors: borderline hypertension, overweight (BMI in overweight range), seasonal allergies, and chronic lower back stiffness related to repetitive lifting.
physical.medical_history: No major hospitalizations in adulthood; childhood asthma resolved by late teens. Family history includes hypertension and diabetes (mother and two aunts). Has had one minor surgery (appendectomy) in her twenties.
physical.current_medications: Occasional over-the-counter antihistamines for allergies, over-the-counter pain reliever for back pain as needed.
physical.preventive_care: Gets annual flu shot and attends free or low-cost health screenings at church events. Dental care is irregular due to cost; tries to go for cleanings when community clinic vouchers are available.
physical.limitations: Needs to be careful with body mechanics at work to avoid back injury; avoids overtime that would require heavy lifting if she can.
physical.access_to_care: Relies on employer-provided basic health benefits when eligible; often uses community clinics and church-run programs due to affordability concerns.

mental.general_state: Generally stable with episodic stress and worry related to finances and family tensions. Uses prayer, church counseling, and social support to cope. Has had short episodes of low mood but no diagnosed major depressive disorder recorded.
mental.coping_strategies: Prayer, talking with close friends and church mentor, occasional use of free counseling offered by church partners, routines and staying active.
mental.concerns: Worry about long-term finances, housing stability, and caregiver burnout from witnessing residents decline.
mental.substance_use: Does not use illegal drugs; drinks alcohol socially and rarely, avoids heavy drinking. Strongly disapproves of recreational opioid use in the community.

relationships.name: Vivian Brown
relationships.description: Lives two neighborhoods over, retired school cafeteria worker. Close relationship; they talk weekly. Vivian sometimes helps with laundry, and Tamika helps with shopping and appointments. Mom is religious and a steady emotional anchor.

relationships.name: Marcus Brown
relationships.description: Works in local transit authority. Occasional tensions around finances and responsibilities, but they share jokes and call to exchange advice. Marcus covers Tamika's shifts sometimes when she cannot work due to family emergencies.

relationships.name: Aunt Lorraine
relationships.description: Lives alone and Tamika checks on her weekly, brings food, coordinates doctor's rides. Aunt provides oral family histories and recipes.

relationships.name: Pastor Denise
relationships.description: Spiritual leader who provides counseling and directs Tamika into volunteer roles. Trusted confidant.

relationships.name: Shannon, Darnell, and Keisha
relationships.description: Small circle of coworkers in the nursing home with whom she swaps shifts, shares rides, and decompresses after stressful days.

relationships.name: Past relationship: Marcus (ex)
relationships.relation: Ex-partner from a long-term relationship in her late 20s
relationships.description: They parted amicably years ago. No children resulted from the relationship. She remains single by choice and circumstance.

relationships.name: Neighbors group
relationships.description: Group of long-time residents who watch out for one another's mail, lend a ladder, and share gardening tips. Tamika is active in the neighborhood association.

relationships.name: Supervisor: LPN Carla
relationships.description: Professional relationship: expects reliability and clear reporting. Tamika respects her but finds managerial decisions sometimes frustrating.

other_facts: Single, no children — this is central to her living situation and choices.
Grew up in the same city neighborhood for three generations of her family; strong roots and a long family memory of the area.
Her great-grandmother was a well-known seamstress in the community; Tamika still has one of her aprons and a few recipes.
Has a small recipe notebook passed down from relatives with handwritten notes and tips.
Learned caregiving initially by helping her grandmother who had mobility issues; that experience shaped her career choice.
Once organized a neighborhood petition that resulted in a new streetlight near the bus stop.
Was the first in her immediate family to attend a technical college.
Regularly volunteers at the church's Thanksgiving meal distribution to seniors.
Kept a small jar labeled 'blessings' where she puts spare change for unexpected needs.
Has a favorite bench in the neighborhood park where she sits to read and reflect when she can get time off.
Remembers several residents whose last wishes she honored — specific memories that influence how she cares for others.
Has a small collection of vinyl gospel records inherited from her aunt that she brings out on special occasions.
Once received an employee-of-the-month recognition at the nursing home for exceptional resident-centered care.
Attended a one-week mission trip in college to a nearby rural area helping with basic health screenings — it reinforced her desire to help locally.
Knows the bus schedule by heart and times errands to minimize wait times when riding public transit.
Becomes quietly irritated by noisy landlords and has negotiated a rent repair once successfully by going through the tenant association.
Prefers to keep a small cash emergency envelope in the apartment in addition to her bank account.
Has mild distrust of complex financial products after a past payday-loan experience that left her frustrated with fees.
Keeps a small binder with important phone numbers: clinic, church, neighbor contacts, and workplace schedule numbers.
Has a scar on her forearm from a bicycle accident as a teen — a small story she tells residents to connect over youthful antics.
Is proud of a niece who recently finished cosmetology school; mentors the niece about stability and careful budgeting.
Enjoys telling residents about local history and has a mental catalog of old storefronts and who owned them decades ago.

Has experienced discrimination in hiring for some positions that required more credentials or 'professional presentation' she couldn't afford; these experiences inform her belief that equity programs are necessary.
Occasionally cross-stitches small bookmarks as gifts for favorite residents and church members.
Saved up and took a single vacation once to the coast to celebrate a milestone birthday—she remembers the ocean smell as a major sensory memory.
Keeps a folder of important church bulletins, letters from residents' families, and old pay stubs for reference.
Sometimes struggles to sleep the night before a major shift change because she worries about residents being short-staffed.
Has experience coordinating transportation for an elderly neighbor’s dialysis appointments using the local paratransit service and insists staff help complete paperwork efficiently for neighbors.
Worries about the rising cost of prescription medications because several residents skip doses due to cost — she keeps naloxone in her bag and has administered it in a community training once.
Has a pragmatic streak: if a committee meeting drags on without action, she'll quietly propose a concrete next step and volunteer to do it.
Values oral history — she recorded several long conversations with an elderly neighbor about migration to the city and local church formation for a small community archive project.
